children.subject: No.   First off there is an outer loop in DFS that goes over all unvisited vertices.  The highest postorder # is the last vertex considered.  If you start DFS from a source vertex v (that can also reach every other vertex) then v will have the highest postorder #.  Otherwise it will not.  If you start from a non-source vertex z then DFS will first visit those vertices reachable from z.  Afterwards it will consider an unvisited vertex in this outer loop, and those later vertices will have higher post # than z.

Also in GR1 - DAG Structure you say that the vertex with the highest post order # is going to be a source vertex. But in a DFS wouldn't the node that you arbitrarily chose always have the highest post order number? The root is always the highest, so this isn't inherent in the graph, its a property of the DAG that DFS produces.

history.content:
It's true from any starting vertex.

The key is that there is an outer loop in DFS so that you go over all vertices, and run explore on them if they are not visited yet.  This is why it doesn't matter if the cycle C is reachable from the first vertex considered or not.  You will discover the entire graph.

So as I understand it, we build a tree with DFS to reach all reachable nodes in a Graph starting from some node S. We can detect if there are cycles because the post order number.

However, is that true from any starting point S?

Clearly there could be unreachable nodes and also nodes that when taken in a certain direction could hide the cycle. 

How would we choose S?
history.subject: GR1- Cycles: DFS and Back Edges
